original_text: A limitation of the pharmacyte approach is the one-time nature of the intervention: ACT T-cells can only be loaded once with a cargo of adjuvant drug prior to transfer, and the duration of stimulation is inherently limited by expansion of the cell population in vivo, since cell-bound particles are diluted with each cell division. We hypothesized that a strategy to target supporting drugs to T-cells with nanoparticle drug carriers directly in vivo would enable transferred lymphocytes to be repeatedly stimulated with supporting adjuvant drugs, and thereby provide continuous supporting signals over the prolonged durations that might be necessary for elimination of large tumor burdens. Such re-arming of T-cells with supporting drugs could be achieved by repeated administration of targeted particles, allowing adoptively-transferred T-cells to be restimulated multiple times directly in vivo, while the use of internalizing targeting ligands would minimize the likelihood of immune responses against the nanoparticle carrier. To our knowledge, only two prior studies have attempted to target nanoparticles to T-cells in vivo [17,18]. In both of these studies, particles were targeted to T-cells via peptide-MHC ligands that bind to specific T-cell receptors. However, peptide-MHC-functionalized nanoparticles have recently been shown to deliver an anergizing/tolerizing signal to T-cells [18,19] — which is ideal for treating graft rejection or autoimmunity, but runs counter to the goals of cancer immunotherapy.
original_translation: Una limitación del enfoque de las farmacocitos es la naturaleza única de la intervención: las células T ACT solo pueden cargarse una vez con un fármaco adyuvante antes de la transferencia, y la duración de la estimulación está inherentemente limitada por la expansión de la población celular in vivo, ya que las partículas unidas a las células se diluyen con cada división celular. Hipotetizamos que una estrategia para dirigir fármacos de apoyo a las células T con transportadores de fármacos de nanopartículas directamente in vivo permitiría que los linfocitos transferidos fueran estimulados repetidamente con fármacos adyuvantes de apoyo, y así proporcionar señales de apoyo continuas durante las duraciones prolongadas que podrían ser necesarias para la eliminación de grandes cargas tumorales. Este rearmamento de las células T con fármacos de apoyo podría lograrse mediante la administración repetida de partículas dirigidas, permitiendo que las células T transferidas de forma adoptiva sean reestimuladas múltiples veces directamente in vivo, mientras que el uso de ligandos de targeting internalizantes minimizaría la probabilidad de respuestas inmunes contra el transportador de nanopartículas. Hasta donde sabemos, solo dos estudios previos han intentado dirigir nanopartículas a las células T in vivo [17,18]. En ambos de estos estudios, las partículas se dirigieron a las células T a través de ligandos péptido-MHC que se unen a receptores específicos de células T. Sin embargo, se ha demostrado recientemente que las nanopartículas funcionalizadas con péptido-MHC entregan una señal anergizante/tolerizante a las células T [18,19] —lo cual es ideal para tratar el rechazo de injertos o la autoinmunidad, pero va en contra de los objetivos de la inmunoterapia del cáncer.

original_annotated_sentences:
A limitation of the pharmacyte approach is the one-time nature of the intervention: ACT T-cells can only be loaded once with a cargo of adjuvant drug prior to transfer, and the duration of stimulation is inherently limited by expansion of the cell population in vivo, since
cell-bound particles
are diluted with each cell division.

We hypothesized that a strategy to target supporting drugs to T-cells with nanoparticle drug carriers directly in vivo would enable transferred lymphocytes to be repeatedly stimulated with supporting adjuvant drugs, and thereby provide continuous supporting signals over the prolonged durations that might be necessary for elimination of large tumor burdens.

Such re-arming of T-cells with supporting drugs could be achieved by repeated administration of targeted particles, allowing adoptively-transferred T-cells to be restimulated multiple times directly in vivo, while the use of internalizing targeting ligands would minimize the likelihood of immune responses against the nanoparticle carrier.
To our knowledge, only two prior studies have attempted to target nanoparticles to T-cells in vivo [17,18].
In both of these studies, particles were targeted to T-cells via peptide-MHC ligands that bind to specific T-cell receptors.

However, peptide-MHC-functionalized nanoparticles have recently been shown to deliver an anergizing/tolerizing signal to T-cells [18,19] — which is ideal for treating graft rejection or autoimmunity, but runs counter to the goals of cancer immunotherapy.

Hipotetizamos que una estrategia para dirigir fármacos de apoyo a las células T con transportadores de fármacos de nanopartículas directamente in vivo permitiría que los linfocitos transferidos fueran estimulados repetidamente con fármacos adyuvantes de apoyo, y así proporcionar señales de apoyo continuas durante las duraciones prolongadas que podrían ser necesarias para la eliminación de grandes cargas tumorales. Este rearmamento de las células T con fármacos de apoyo podría lograrse mediante la administración repetida de partículas dirigidas, permitiendo que las células T transferidas de forma adoptiva sean reestimuladas múltiples veces directamente in vivo, mientras que el uso de ligandos de targeting internalizantes minimizaría la probabilidad de respuestas inmunes contra el transportador de nanopartículas. nanopartículas

We hypothesized that a strategy to target supporting drugs to T-cells with nanoparticle drug carriers directly in vivo would enable transferred lymphocytes to be repeatedly stimulated with supporting adjuvant drugs, and thereby provide continuous supporting signals over the prolonged durations that might be necessary for elimination of large tumor burdens.

Such re-arming of T-cells with supporting drugs could be achieved by repeated administration of targeted particles, allowing adoptively-transferred T-cells to be restimulated multiple times directly in vivo, while the use of internalizing targeting ligands would minimize the likelihood of immune responses against the nanoparticle carrier.

Hasta donde sabemos, solo dos estudios previos han intentado dirigir nanopartículas a las células T in vivo [17,18]. En ambos de estos estudios, las partículas se dirigieron a las células T a través de ligandos péptido-MHC que se unen a receptores específicos de células T. Sin embargo, se ha demostrado recientemente que las nanopartículas funcionalizadas con péptido-MHC entregan una señal anergizante/tolerizante a las células T [18,19] —lo cual es ideal para tratar el rechazo de injertos o la autoinmunidad, pero va en contra de los objetivos de la inmunoterapia del cáncer.

original_annotated_sentences: A limitation of the pharmacyte approach is the one-time nature of the intervention: ACT T-cells can only be loaded once with a cargo of adjuvant drug prior to transfer, and the duration of stimulation is inherently limited by expansion of the cell population in vivo, since cell-bound particles are diluted with each cell division.

We hypothesized that a strategy to target supporting drugs to T-cells with nanoparticle drug carriers directly in vivo would enable transferred lymphocytes to be repeatedly stimulated with supporting adjuvant drugs, and thereby provide continuous supporting signals over the prolonged durations that might be necessary for elimination of large tumor burdens.

Such re-arming of T-cells with supporting drugs could be achieved by repeated administration of
targeted particles
, allowing adoptively-transferred T-cells to be restimulated multiple times directly in vivo, while the use of internalizing targeting ligands would minimize the likelihood of immune responses against the nanoparticle carrier.
To our knowledge, only two prior studies have attempted to target nanoparticles to T-cells in vivo [17,18].
In both of these studies, particles were targeted to T-cells via peptide-MHC ligands that bind to specific T-cell receptors.

However, peptide-MHC-functionalized nanoparticles have recently been shown to deliver an anergizing/tolerizing signal to T-cells [18,19] — which is ideal for treating graft rejection or autoimmunity, but runs counter to the goals of cancer immunotherapy.
